Description.text: The top-level feature representing an application instantiated from the OBS Framework
The application manages one or more control actions

FeatureComment.text: Mode dependency for control action can be realized either using the ModeManager feature, or by attaching the individual control actions (which are punctual actions) to the states of an FSM

Description.text: Control management is mode-based
The control actions managed by the application
The data pool
The data pool options envisaged by the framework
An application-specific data pool not provided by the framework
A data pool with basic functionalities and minimal overheads

The size in bytes of the data pool
An item in the data pool
The attributes of the data pool item
The numerical identifier of the data pool item

FeatureComment.text: Constraint: the id must be less than the data pool size

Description.text: The name of the data pool item
The syntactical type of the data pool item

A finite state machine

The state of a finite state machine (FSM)

The index of the FsmState in its FSM (recall: the FsmState with index 0 is the default state

The name of the next state to which an autonomous transition may be made after this state is exited
The enable status of transitions into this state has a non-default initial value
The name of a punctual action that must be executed in this FsmState
The FsmState options foreseen by the framework
Unstable FsmState that exits immediately after being entered
FmsState that takes no action and performs no check
Activate a nested FSM until it has reached a certain target state

The name of the nested FSM
The name of the target FsmState in the nested FSM
Activate a nested FSM and allow exit from the FsmState only if the target FSM has reached a certain target state

The name of the target FsmState in the nested FSM

The FsmState performs an initialization action
The FsmState performs a continuation action
The FsmState performs an exit action
The FsmState performs an entry check
The FsmState performs an exit check
The FsmState performs a termination check

The state-changing event of a Finite State Machine (FSM)

GroupComment.text: The target FSM is implicitly defined (it is the FSM of which this feature is a child)

Description.text: The name of the target state

There is a dependency on operational mode controlled by a mode manager

FeatureComment.text: Constraint: this name must match one of the mode names

Description.text: A mode into which transition is disabled
A monitoring profile

The monitoring profile has a non-default initial enable status
The monitoring profiles foreseen by the framework
A delta profile (triggers if monitored value jumps by more than a threshold)
The parameters of the profile
The triggering threshold
An out-of-range profile (triggers if monitored value goes outside range [lowerBound,upperBound])
The parameters of the profile
The lower bound
The upper bound
An in-range profile (triggers if monitored value goes inside range [lowerBound,upperBound])
The parameters of the profile
The lower bound
The upper bound
A stuck data profile (triggers if monitored value remains stuck at constant value for longer than a threshold number of cycles)
The parameters of the profile
The triggering threshold
A forbidden value profile (triggers if monitored value has a certain "forbidden" value)
The parameters of the profile
The forbidden value
An application-specific profile
The default attributes of the profile

FeatureComment.text: It is also possible to direct enter the control action name in the FSM model as one of the punctual actions associated to a state of an FSM

Description.text: The control action has an activation condition

The application manages one or more FDIR Checks

FeatureComment.text: Mode dependency for FDIR Checks can be realized either using the ModeManager feature, or by attaching the individual FDIR Checks (which are punctual actions) to the states of an FSM

Description.text: FDIR management is mode-based

GroupComment.text: Constraint: There can only be one punctual action associated to an FDIR Check
